title: Episode 08 – Mark Retzloff – Business Leader, Organic Food Brands & Systems
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[9.7s - 15.3s]: Hi friends, welcome to another edition of the Y on Earth communities stewardship and

[15.3s - 17.1s]: sustainability podcast series.

[17.8s - 22.3s]: And today we have the opportunity to visit with Mark Retzloff.

[22.7s - 22.9s]: Hi Mark.

[23.6s - 24.4s]: How you doing?

[24.6s - 25.2s]: Good to see you.

[25.4s - 26.0s]: Good to see you.

[26.9s - 32.8s]: And welcome to our show and thank you for welcoming us to your beautiful home here.

[33.5s - 33.8s]: Thank you.

[34.0s - 34.7s]: Thanks for coming out.

[35.9s - 37.1s]: It's amazing.

[37.1s - 44.7s]: We'll mention that on this property of Mark's are some tremendous biodynamic gardens and

[45.4s - 47.7s]: maybe we'll get to that in a few moments.

[48.1s - 54.6s]: But before diving in, Mark, I just want to share with our audience that your career,

[55.6s - 70.5s]: spans a number of really interesting business stories and really follows the arc of so much of how our food system here in our society has evolved over the last several decades.

[71.4s - 80.9s]: And I know that in your college days you started what would become Eden, foods and rainbow, one of the distributors.

[80.9s - 90.8s]: You went on to found the first iteration of alfalfa, which got acquired by wild oats and ultimately became part of whole foods.

[91.0s - 102.6s]: And then also were one of the founders of Horizon Organic Dairy driving thousands of acres into organic feed production.

[103.6s - 121.2s]: And you've also been very involved in Waldorf education and sit on many boards, university boards advising the next generations of leaders, business boards and other boards in the community.

[121.9s - 127.9s]: And I thought that we'd have a really fun and rich conversation Mark covering some of those highlights.

[127.9s - 139.9s]: But I'd like to start by asking you take us back to your college days and paint the picture for us. What was that like and what got started then?

[140.6s - 151.8s]: Okay. So I grew up in Michigan and started at the University of Michigan in 1966.

[152.6s - 164.2s]: So it was right at the height of the Vietnam War. And obviously Michigan was a hotbed of the anti-war movement.

[166.9s - 179.3s]: And as I got oriented there and began looking at what I was doing, you know, I got interested in that, became part of the involved in the anti-war movement at the university in Ann Arbor.

[181.8s - 192.6s]: And you know, met a lot of the people who ended up being, you know, leaders in that Tom Hayden and Bill Ayers.

[193.5s - 201.4s]: But you know, part of that splintered off and became the weatherman which became more, you know, violent.

[201.4s - 212.4s]: And I kind of got turned me off because here we were, you know, we were anti-war activists fighting for the end of our participation in it.

[212.5s - 220.1s]: And, you know, some of these activists had gotten very violent in what they were doing. It just didn't make a lot of sense.

[220.1s - 235.4s]: And so I kind of transferred my attention to environmental issues and changed what I was doing in school, enrolled in the School of Natural Resources, and became an environmental activist in many ways.

[235.4s - 245.4s]: Was there for the first Earth Day? And then my two roommates and myself began changing our diet.

[245.4s - 258.1s]: It became, at that time, a macrobiotics was a burgeoning type of diet, you know, based on, you know, oriental Japanese type of healthy diet.

[259.0s - 264.8s]: And we started doing that. We'd moved out to a farm outside of Ann Arbor.

[265.9s - 278.6s]: And I was, at that time I was going to still finish it up my last year. And my one roommate had graduated and the other one had dropped out.

[279.2s - 290.9s]: And so as we were trying to find these foods that we were using in this diet, you know, we had to drive an hour or two to Detroit to pick up stuff. And that didn't make sense to us either.

[291.9s - 302.4s]: So we decided to start the first co-op in Ann Arbor food co-op. And we did that. And what year was up? 1969.

[303.0s - 306.8s]: So this was just as the food co-op movement was getting started?

[307.3s - 320.9s]: Yeah, very, very beginning of that. And so we did that. We just could not generate the interest to make that work. And we began realizing also that there was an opportunity to make that work.

[320.9s - 325.9s]: And we had an opportunity for us to take it beyond students, the people who lived in Ann Arbor and so on and so forth.

[326.5s - 339.8s]: So we changed it from a co-op into a retail business. It was called Eden Foods, the precursor of the Eden Foods today, which is one of the leading organic food producers in the country.

[341.5s - 359.0s]: And so I got involved in that. Though I was still going to school finishing up my last year. So my role in that organization was to go and talk to farmers and to that who could produce products that we could use.

[359.0s - 367.3s]: And we became a, besides the retail store, we started doing some distributed to other co-ops and stores in the Midwest.

[370.3s - 379.6s]: And so one of the, I can remember one of the conversations I had with a farmer outside of Ann Arbor called Tom Vryland.

[380.4s - 386.5s]: And I went and was sitting in his kitchen, which is where you normally have conversations with farmers.

[387.0s - 407.0s]: Okay. And I was asking him to produce products organically, corn and field beans like lentils and maybe beans, different varieties of wheat and some rye and stuff like that.

[408.8s - 416.9s]: And he said, well, you know, yeah, I can do that. And I said, well, I need them to be done organically. And he said, well, what's that?

[417.4s - 435.8s]: And there was no standard for organic at that time. I mean, it was, and so I put together what I thought it would be based on readings from J.I. Rodell and from Fyfer and Rudolph Steiner, so on that I was reading at that time.

[439.0s - 448.2s]: And so he listened and he said to me, well, that's the way my grandfather and my father grew, things on the farm.

[449.2s - 454.9s]: He said, so I could easily do that. Are you going to pay me a little bit more of a premium? I said sure, of course.

[455.9s - 475.5s]: And then we got chatting about it and about exactly what I wanted him to do. And he said something to me, which was pretty profound at that time for me and had a major impact on me, is that he said, you know, if there's a market for the products, the farmers will grow it.

[476.7s - 486.2s]: So I said to him, that's interesting. And I began thinking about that and I began realizing, well, I'm not going to be a farmer.

[488.9s - 502.0s]: So my job is to produce that market because farmers will then change to do that. And that made a lot of sense to me because in getting my degree in conservation and resource planning,

[502.0s - 522.2s]: I had, it was, you know, we did a lot of work on where the sources of pollution was particularly at agriculture. And at that time, which is similar to today, the largest single point of environmental degradation in the country is in agriculture.

[522.2s - 538.2s]: If you include the soil that's being eroded and sent down the waterways, if you include what we put into the soil and then leave it with those things in it, whether it's glyphosate or at that time it wasn't glyphosate, it was chemical fertilizers and pesticides and so forth.

[538.6s - 547.1s]: If you look at what we put up in the air when we spray these things, if we look at the farm worker health, just all those types of things.

[547.1s - 560.6s]: And so I said, okay, well, you know, if I want to change that, the way we're doing that from an environmental standpoint, I got to produce a market so these farmers will have something to, you know, place the cell to once they make the change.

[561.3s - 574.9s]: So I, that's what made sense for me to be in retail. So I ended up staying in retail probably for the next 20 years.

[574.9s - 594.1s]: Yep, yep. And you've seen the markets in that time frame, those first 20 years of your career and then the subsequent 20 years, you've seen the markets evolve so tremendously as it relates to food and organics and food in particular.

[594.1s - 609.5s]: And I'm struck that you have a perspective that really got going at the earliest moments in that movement that is now as widespread and ubiquitous as it is.

[609.5s - 616.3s]: Of course, there's a lot of work to do, but by golly, you've seen so much positive change.

[616.3s - 624.0s]: And I wonder, you know, how does that feel sitting here knowing that you contributed to such positive change?

[626.8s - 634.0s]: Well, I feel really good about, you know, how the evolution is, but I do know that we have a lot of work to do.

[634.7s - 644.6s]: And today, you know, organic foods make up probably certainly less than 10% of what we do.

[645.0s - 652.1s]: Certain categories of fruits and vegetables were up to probably 15, 16% grown in the United States are organic.

[653.0s - 659.5s]: Dairy, which I had a lot of to do with, it's probably up close to about 8%.

[660.1s - 666.9s]: And these are all growing as categories as a percentage of the total part of those products.

[667.4s - 676.9s]: And I'm very encouraged by the younger generation, the millennials and the next generation, whatever we're going to end up calling them.

[676.9s - 687.0s]: Z, huh? Why in Z, right? Z, probably. But anyway, so, yeah, there's been, you know, a lot of change, but we still have a long way to go.

[687.4s - 706.9s]: Yeah. One of the things that strikes me, Mark, you shared the other day that it was a soil ecology class that you took in the 60s that really furthered your understanding of that important place and point in our entire world.

[711.5s - 725.7s]: And I'm sure that today, so much of the conversation is around soil and that soil is not only essential for health and nutrition is not only essential for clean, safe water.

[725.7s - 737.3s]: But of course, is also we know very linked to climate change and building soil is very linked to reversing climate change and stabilizing our climate.

[737.7s - 747.3s]: And I'm just so impressed that it was soil at the get-go for you that really helped to set some things in motion.

[747.3s - 759.8s]: And I'm curious if you could give some pithy advice to the younger entrepreneurs out there thinking about soil, what would you tell them? What would you tell us?

[761.8s - 789.2s]: Well, it's not just dirt, first of all. Yeah, okay. It's soil. And in the soil with, you know, it is really the lifebed for all the plants grow. And obviously for not just the plant world from the animal world because most of them eat plants or some derivative of the plant world for their own health

[789.2s - 812.2s]: and for their growth. And where does that all start? It all starts in the dirt in the soil. Yeah, we have that. So I was very fortunate. I had an instructor at the University of Michigan, a Dr. Bob Zonner, who taught soil science.

[812.2s - 835.4s]: And he was a very creative, very innovative individual, got it, understood what was going on with the microorganisms and the transformations that were happy to feed the plants and how that fed all of the animal kingdom.

[835.4s - 854.0s]: And I was lucky that I was in a class and that we did projects. So I decided to do a, at the vatatical gardens there, did a study between growing dicon radishes both organically and non-organically.

[854.0s - 866.7s]: And see if there was any difference in the plants and in the nutrients that were in the plants and that stuff. It was a very cursory type of thing.

[866.7s - 881.9s]: But again, it was, we saw slight differences and it was just done one time. But it, for me, it began to really understanding that it's really dirt first.

[881.9s - 903.4s]: Yeah, okay. If we can work with our soil and that substrate that's growing all these plants, that's growing the animals that we need for our nutrition and for other uses, whether it's for our peril with fibers or whatever it is.

[903.4s - 916.7s]: So, yeah, and it's still the same here. That led me into reading a lot of things like the more of the rodeo stuff that was coming out at that time,

[916.7s - 946.7s]: the Deuteronica, the Flutopps, the Vyper, and his books, the Fruit of Scyder, about Dynamics. Farmers for 40 centuries. The agricultural testament by Albert Howard. All those kind of, like, you know, the foundations of conservation and regenerative organic, whatever you wanna call it, agriculture, which goes back literally, you know, to when we first started growing food for our society,

[946.7s - 948.9s]: ourselves as human beings.

[949.4s - 950.7s]: Yes, thousands of years ago.

[950.9s - 951.7s]: Thousands of years.

[952.0s - 954.5s]: And that's what the farmers for 40 centuries is about.

[955.4s - 960.0s]: Back, the techniques and the way they did things back there

[960.0s - 963.3s]: are not much different than the way we're doing things now.

[963.5s - 966.7s]: We probably know a lot more about it and all these things

[966.7s - 969.2s]: and the mechanisms and the systems and how they work.

[970.0s - 971.7s]: So we should be able to do a better job.

[972.4s - 972.6s]: Right.

[973.4s - 973.4s]:

[977.2s - 981.2s]: And that is that those movements are growing

[981.2s - 982.9s]: and becoming stronger and stronger.

[983.5s - 985.5s]: And probably they're more important today

[985.5s - 990.6s]: than ever before because of the impact that it can have

[990.6s - 994.6s]: on what's going on in our climate in this world today.

[995.8s - 999.2s]: And climate change, the ability to sequester carbon

[999.2s - 1003.1s]: that agricultural, good agricultural practices

[1021.2s - 1022.5s]: and further forward.

[1049.1s - 1049.1s]: Yeah.

[1052.7s - 1054.8s]: So, and, you know, I work with the Center

[1054.8s - 1058.0s]: for Ethics and Social Responsibility,

[1058.0s - 1060.1s]: which I think fits hand in hand

[1060.1s - 1062.4s]: with good agricultural practices.

[1290.4s - 1292.9s]: into one big movement, but that movement

[1292.9s - 1296.5s]: in that direction is positive for us.

[1300.1s - 1302.8s]: Well, one of the things I wonder about,

[1302.9s - 1305.8s]: especially as it relates to communication technology

[1305.8s - 1308.5s]: is a few generations ago,

segments.text: Hi friends, welcome to another edition of the Y on Earth communities stewardship and
sustainability podcast series.
And today we have the opportunity to visit with Mark Retzloff.
Hi Mark.
How you doing?
Good to see you.
Good to see you.
And welcome to our show and thank you for welcoming us to your beautiful home here.
Thank you.
Thanks for coming out.
It's amazing.
We'll mention that on this property of Mark's are some tremendous biodynamic gardens and
maybe we'll get to that in a few moments.
But before diving in, Mark, I just want to share with our audience that your career,
spans a number of really interesting business stories and really follows the arc of so much of how our food system here in our society has evolved over the last several decades.
And I know that in your college days you started what would become Eden, foods and rainbow, one of the distributors.
You went on to found the first iteration of alfalfa, which got acquired by wild oats and ultimately became part of whole foods.
And then also were one of the founders of Horizon Organic Dairy driving thousands of acres into organic feed production.
And you've also been very involved in Waldorf education and sit on many boards, university boards advising the next generations of leaders, business boards and other boards in the community.
And I thought that we'd have a really fun and rich conversation Mark covering some of those highlights.
But I'd like to start by asking you take us back to your college days and paint the picture for us. What was that like and what got started then?
Okay. So I grew up in Michigan and started at the University of Michigan in 1966.
So it was right at the height of the Vietnam War. And obviously Michigan was a hotbed of the anti-war movement.
And as I got oriented there and began looking at what I was doing, you know, I got interested in that, became part of the involved in the anti-war movement at the university in Ann Arbor.
And you know, met a lot of the people who ended up being, you know, leaders in that Tom Hayden and Bill Ayers.
But you know, part of that splintered off and became the weatherman which became more, you know, violent.
And I kind of got turned me off because here we were, you know, we were anti-war activists fighting for the end of our participation in it.
And, you know, some of these activists had gotten very violent in what they were doing. It just didn't make a lot of sense.

And so I kind of transferred my attention to environmental issues and changed what I was doing in school, enrolled in the School of Natural Resources, and became an environmental activist in many ways.
Was there for the first Earth Day? And then my two roommates and myself began changing our diet.
It became, at that time, a macrobiotics was a burgeoning type of diet, you know, based on, you know, oriental Japanese type of healthy diet.
And we started doing that. We'd moved out to a farm outside of Ann Arbor.
And I was, at that time I was going to still finish it up my last year. And my one roommate had graduated and the other one had dropped out.
And so as we were trying to find these foods that we were using in this diet, you know, we had to drive an hour or two to Detroit to pick up stuff. And that didn't make sense to us either.
So we decided to start the first co-op in Ann Arbor food co-op. And we did that. And what year was up? 1969.
So this was just as the food co-op movement was getting started?
Yeah, very, very beginning of that. And so we did that. We just could not generate the interest to make that work. And we began realizing also that there was an opportunity to make that work.
And we had an opportunity for us to take it beyond students, the people who lived in Ann Arbor and so on and so forth.
So we changed it from a co-op into a retail business. It was called Eden Foods, the precursor of the Eden Foods today, which is one of the leading organic food producers in the country.

And so I got involved in that. Though I was still going to school finishing up my last year. So my role in that organization was to go and talk to farmers and to that who could produce products that we could use.
And we became a, besides the retail store, we started doing some distributed to other co-ops and stores in the Midwest.
And so one of the, I can remember one of the conversations I had with a farmer outside of Ann Arbor called Tom Vryland.
And I went and was sitting in his kitchen, which is where you normally have conversations with farmers.
Okay. And I was asking him to produce products organically, corn and field beans like lentils and maybe beans, different varieties of wheat and some rye and stuff like that.
And he said, well, you know, yeah, I can do that. And I said, well, I need them to be done organically. And he said, well, what's that?

And there was no standard for organic at that time. I mean, it was, and so I put together what I thought it would be based on readings from J.I. Rodell and from Fyfer and Rudolph Steiner, so on that I was reading at that time.
And so he listened and he said to me, well, that's the way my grandfather and my father grew, things on the farm.
He said, so I could easily do that. Are you going to pay me a little bit more of a premium? I said sure, of course.

And then we got chatting about it and about exactly what I wanted him to do. And he said something to me, which was pretty profound at that time for me and had a major impact on me, is that he said, you know, if there's a market for the products, the farmers will grow it.
So I said to him, that's interesting. And I began thinking about that and I began realizing, well, I'm not going to be a farmer.
So my job is to produce that market because farmers will then change to do that. And that made a lot of sense to me because in getting my degree in conservation and resource planning,

I had, it was, you know, we did a lot of work on where the sources of pollution was particularly at agriculture. And at that time, which is similar to today, the largest single point of environmental degradation in the country is in agriculture.

If you include the soil that's being eroded and sent down the waterways, if you include what we put into the soil and then leave it with those things in it, whether it's glyphosate or at that time it wasn't glyphosate, it was chemical fertilizers and pesticides and so forth.
If you look at what we put up in the air when we spray these things, if we look at the farm worker health, just all those types of things.

And so I said, okay, well, you know, if I want to change that, the way we're doing that from an environmental standpoint, I got to produce a market so these farmers will have something to, you know, place the cell to once they make the change.
So I, that's what made sense for me to be in retail. So I ended up staying in retail probably for the next 20 years.

Yep, yep. And you've seen the markets in that time frame, those first 20 years of your career and then the subsequent 20 years, you've seen the markets evolve so tremendously as it relates to food and organics and food in particular.
And I'm struck that you have a perspective that really got going at the earliest moments in that movement that is now as widespread and ubiquitous as it is.
Of course, there's a lot of work to do, but by golly, you've seen so much positive change.
And I wonder, you know, how does that feel sitting here knowing that you contributed to such positive change?
Well, I feel really good about, you know, how the evolution is, but I do know that we have a lot of work to do.
And today, you know, organic foods make up probably certainly less than 10% of what we do.
Certain categories of fruits and vegetables were up to probably 15, 16% grown in the United States are organic.
Dairy, which I had a lot of to do with, it's probably up close to about 8%.
And these are all growing as categories as a percentage of the total part of those products.
And I'm very encouraged by the younger generation, the millennials and the next generation, whatever we're going to end up calling them.
Z, huh? Why in Z, right? Z, probably. But anyway, so, yeah, there's been, you know, a lot of change, but we still have a long way to go.

Yeah. One of the things that strikes me, Mark, you shared the other day that it was a soil ecology class that you took in the 60s that really furthered your understanding of that important place and point in our entire world.
And I'm sure that today, so much of the conversation is around soil and that soil is not only essential for health and nutrition is not only essential for clean, safe water.
But of course, is also we know very linked to climate change and building soil is very linked to reversing climate change and stabilizing our climate.
And I'm just so impressed that it was soil at the get-go for you that really helped to set some things in motion.
And I'm curious if you could give some pithy advice to the younger entrepreneurs out there thinking about soil, what would you tell them? What would you tell us?

Well, it's not just dirt, first of all. Yeah, okay. It's soil. And in the soil with, you know, it is really the lifebed for all the plants grow. and for their growth. And where does that all start? It all starts in the dirt in the soil. Yeah, we have that. So I was very fortunate. I had an instructor at the University of Michigan, a Dr. Bob Zonner, who taught soil science.

And he was a very creative, very innovative individual, got it, understood what was going on with the microorganisms and the transformations that were happy to feed the plants and how that fed all of the animal kingdom.
And I was lucky that I was in a class and that we did projects. So I decided to do a, at the vatatical gardens there, did a study between growing dicon radishes both organically and non-organically.
And see if there was any difference in the plants and in the nutrients that were in the plants and that stuff. It was a very cursory type of thing.
But again, it was, we saw slight differences and it was just done one time. But it, for me, it began to really understanding that it's really dirt first.
